intro: Byrsonima guilleminiana, commonly known as the Brazilian cherry or guapira, is a small to medium-sized tree native to South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its elliptical, leathery leaves and showy, clustered pink or red flowers. The plant produces small, round fruits that are typically consumed raw or used in traditional medicine. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in moist, well-drained soils. Its ornamental value and ecological importance make it a notable species in its native habitat.
